column5: You can find the org ID on the CORE service under 'Stock owners' or, if your organisation is the stock owner, under 'About your organisation'

column8: This is how you usually refer to this buyer on your own systems
column9:
Sales logs are no longer required for outright and other sales.

A shared ownership sale is when the purchaser buys an initial share of up to 75% of the property value and pays rent to the Private Registered Provider (PRP) on the remaining portion, or a subsequent staircasing transaction
column10: See specification for full description of each scheme
column11: A staircasing transaction is when the household purchases more shares in their property, increasing the proportion they own and decreasing the proportion the housing association owns. Once the household purchases 100% of the shares, they own the property.
column12: See specification for full description of each scheme
column13: This is where two or more people are named as legal owners of the property after the purchase.
column15: You should still try to answer all questions even if the buyer wasn't interviewed in person
column16: Make sure the buyer has seen or been given access to the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government (MHCLG) privacy notice before completing this log. This is a legal requirement under data protection legislation.
column17:
The Unique Property Reference Number (UPRN) is a unique number system created by Ordnance Survey and used by housing providers and various industries across the UK. An example UPRN is 10010457355. 
The UPRN may not be the same as the property reference assigned by your organisation.
column22: Combined with field 28 it should be a postcode which lies within the local authority given in field 29.

column28: This is whether someone who uses a wheelchair is able to make full use of all of the property’s rooms and facilities, including use of both inside and outside space, and entering and exiting the property.
column29: Buyer 1 is the person in the household who does the most paid work. If it’s a joint purchase and the buyers do the same amount of paid work, buyer 1 is whoever is the oldest.
column30: This should be however they personally choose to identify from the options below. This may or may not be the same as their biological sex or the sex they were assigned at birth.

column79: If the social landlord has previously sold the property to another buyer and is now reselling the property, enter 'yes'. If this is the first time the property has been sold, enter 'no'.

column81: This is the date on which the building contractor hands over responsibility for the completed property to the private registered provider (PRP).
column87: Enter the full purchase price of the property before any discounts are applied. For shared ownership, enter the full purchase price paid for 100% equity (this is equal to the value of the share owned by the PRP plus the value bought by the purchaser).
column88: This is the initial stake purchased. Enter the amount of initial equity held by the purchaser (for example, 25% or 50%)
column90: Enter the amount of mortgage agreed with the mortgage lender. Exclude any deposits or cash payments.
column92: Enter the total cash sum paid by the buyer towards the property that was not funded by the mortgage
column93: Enter the total cash discount given on the property being purchased through the Social HomeBuy scheme
column95: This includes any charges for day-to-day maintenance and repairs, buildings insurance, and any contributions to a sinking or reserve fund. It does not include estate management fees.
column96: Estate management fees are typically used for the maintenance of communal gardens, payments, private roads, car parks or play areas within new build estates.
column99: Back-to-back staircasing transactions are used as a way for shared owners who own less than 100% of their property to sell on the open market. It involves the shared owner purchasing the remaining share from their landlord and immediately selling 100% of the property to a buyer on the open market. The landlord is then reimbursed for the staircasing transaction through the proceeds of sale to the buyer.
column108: Enter the full purchase price of the property before any discounts are applied. For shared ownership, enter the full purchase price paid for 100% equity (this is equal to the value of the share owned by the PRP plus the value bought by the purchaser).
column109: This is the initial stake purchased. Enter the amount of initial equity held by the purchaser (for example, 25% or 50%)
column114: For all schemes, including Right to Acquire (RTA), Right to Buy (RTB), Voluntary Right to Buy (VRTB) or Preserved Right to Buy (PRTB) sales, enter the full price of the property without any discount
column115: For all schemes except Right to Buy (RTB), Preserved Right to Buy (PRTB), Voluntary Right to Buy (VRTB) and Rent to Buy
column116: For Right to Buy (RTB), Preserved Right to Buy (PRTB) and Voluntary Right to Buy (VRTB). For capped discount, enter capped %. If property is sold to an existing tenant under RTB, PRTB or VRTB, enter % discount from full market value.
column118: Enter the amount of mortgage agreed with the mortgage lender. Exclude any deposits or cash payments.

column121: Enter the total cash sum paid by the purchaser towards the property that was not funded by the mortgage. This excludes any grant or loan.
